reviewText:
1. Vibrant Psychedelic Art Direction
2. Catchy Electro Music
3. Lasers, Rainbows, Cosmos, and Beats!
4. Good Vibes

S Y N O P S I S:
Cosmic DJ is a short romp through a wild story about keeping the good vibes flowing through electronic music. Its gameplay revolves around 'jamming' to a preset back track and layering instruments and melodies to move onto the next stage. Don't expect much flexibility in terms of music creation. All the tracks are set to a specific key signature, measure, and tempo. There is also a limited number of instruments to play with for each track; all of which are set to a specific chord progression. These limitations, however, don't detract from the simple fun of jamming along and freestyling the sequence of melodies and instruments. The story is humorous and engaging enough for players to plow through the short 1 hour plot (give or take a few minutes depending on how much the player extends each jam session). Some players may think this is too short without enough content. I'd say that the length of the game is appropriate for the context of this title. The experience will leave a smile on your face once it's through and you'll wish there was more. Luckily, there is some replayability in a Quickplay mode that lets you choose sets of instruments to jam with and create new tunes. One of the best features of the game is its ability to export your jam sessions to MP3s, complete with cover art that you make within the game itself, using the various crazy visuals and stickers they provide. All in all, this is a great indie title for anyone who enjoys rhythm games and quirky, offbeat humor with pop art visuals. Give it a shot!

reviewText:
Cosmic DJ is less of a game and more of a toybox.  By simply pressing four keys at different intervals, you can generate simple 2-measure sequences of electronic music in 4/4.  It sounds basic, but with its variety of different instruments (drum kits, synthesizers, vocoders, odd samples, and many others), grid-based editing, and post-play remixes, anyone can make a song that can range anywhere between decent to amazing.

The presentation style is absurd and comical.  The vivid colors, animations, and effects can probably be described better by video gameplay rather than this review.  I found the dialogue to be humorous, but could be considered strange or obnoxious.

I wouldn't recommend this to a general audience, but it does have a very strong recommendation to anyone who likes electronic music, unique atmospheres, or just something completely different.

reviewText:
A perfectly executed source of pure fun!

It's hard to explain why I am still so in love with this little game/toybox, because it doesn't sound like much. Basically, imagine a tiny music sequencer, simplify it until a three year old can use it, populate it with a weird and weirdly entertaining collection of samples (dog-bark syntesizers anyone?), add some fascinatingly odd visuals and a trippy story, mix it all up with acid and make the head of an utterly crazy yet completely adorable corgi drive it into space. Get the idea? No? I don't blame you, I wouldn't have believed that this could possibly work as a game either.

The campaign is admittedly very short but makes up for it by offering you one of the most ridiculously awesome stories you could have never imagined. And after you've recovered from that experience, you're still left with the quick play, a super simplified but surprisingly fun little sequencer that is there for you every time you need a 15-minute boost of joy in your day. If you like the idea of fiddling with music and beats, even if you've never tried anything like this before, you need to give this little marvel a go. Fear not your musical incompetence, I am persuaded that the game is rigged to make whatever odd things you create sound brilliant despite your worse efforts.

Cosmic DJ is not a game, it is the perfect cheer-me-up machine, the cheapest happy pill on the market. For some strange reason I have a stupid smile plastered on my face every time I fire it up, and every time without exception I feel like hugging the devs afterwards. If it also gave me the munchies I'd be surprised it was legal. ;)

This game is short, sweet, and for those itching to make a quick beat.

Gameplay wise, this game will have you dishing out beats using many different instruments. I find it delightful when I make a beat that just sounds pretty damn good, and if you enjoy what you made, you have the option to save the music so you can listen to it later. Also, the number of levels are few, but each are fun and offer a unique style that would most likely intrigue you, whether it be the rocket corgis or the flailing puppets.

Moving on to what I have to say about the graphics, I must say, they are charming and I enjoy the retro feel of it all. The game is bright and colorful, and the levels offer different styles to keep things wacky and strange, which I enjoy about this game. It's quirkiness and humor is enjoyable.

The audio, oh, the audio. Being that this is a rhythm game, the music features catchy techno tunes that will have you bobbing your head as you create your music. Also, the narrator, a funky shaped fellow, has an... how should I say... enticing voice.

Overall, this is a game that should be played if you enjoy music, want to create it, and want to experience the quirky world that is Cosmic DJ. Considering the low price, this game is well worth trying.

All in all, if you enjoy music games or if you're interested in electronic music composition, give this one a try.

reviewText:
Just download a free step sequencer like Hydrogen.

Note that although cheap, this game has only about a hundred minutes of gameplay. It doesn't offer a particularly featureful or powerful step sequencer. I doubt I'll touch it again.

This is a gamified tutorial for using a step sequencer. If the game was far longer and introduced more and more features from major step sequencers and itself had a fully featured one built in, it'd be better. It'd be nice if you could reach the point where this produces results similar to what you can achieve with something like Hydrogen. As it is though, there are only a few builtin song structures, your sequences are limited to 8 bars, and there is no kind of song editor nor any kind of automation for mixing or effects.

The content of this game is pretty much clean, so it might be good if you have kids.

The story is light and doesn't get too deep into anything, and always manages to have a little humor sprinkled here and there. This game is perfect for those wanting to have fun with music, and get really creative/funky with it at the same time.

There is a certain charm from simulation games which allows anyone, even the ones who haven’t attended any music classes, to easily create their own content. You bring home a sense of accomplishment you don’t often find in other games. Cosmic DJ is one good example of this type of game.

You are the cosmic DJ

You, a floating no face protagonist, are deemed the cosmic DJ by STEVE3, the cosmic conductor of the universe. After learning how to create your own beats and making everyone in the party rock to your groove, STEVE4 crashes the city with bad vibes. It is now up to you to fix the jamtennas with some sweet tracks.

Gameplay

Calling Cosmic DJ a game may not be entirely appropriate. This isn’t like dance revolution or guitar hero where you need to correctly follow a certain QTE like sequence in order to play the tracks correctly. There are also no game overs or consequence to be had here (except for some ear damaging music).

In Cosmic DJ, you play out a scene which is separated into four parts. You select which instruments to play during these parts. You are then presented with a sequencer to input the notes of the instruments. Once you filled in enough notes (regardless of sequence), you are given the option of adding a new instrument to play during a part of the scene. In order to advance to the next part of the scene, you need to fill the “joy” bar by adding enough notes to play the instruments.

Once you finish a scene, you can save the track you created as an MP3 file. While the game encodes the track, you can create the cover art which will be attached to the file you are creating. The game allows you to save your MP3 in any folder in your hard drive.

Presentation
The art style of the game is something straight out of the 80s. From the neon colours to the 3D pixel characters, everything fits the theme of Cosmic DJ. When an instrument plays, you get a visual cue of it playing at the top part of the screen.

My thoughts
One major flaw of Cosmic DJ is its limitation of options in creating your own music track. You create about 60% of the music track where the notes you inserted plays along with the main sequence of the track. There aren’t any other options to help you customise your music to your liking such as controlling the tempo. Since this is just an early access game, gl33k might add more options and sequences for the full retail version.

After creating three tracks, I thought anyone can just mash buttons in order to create a decent track. Turns out this isn’t the case.
Here is one of the good ones I made:

http://picosong.com/c5eX/

Here is the intended bad one (decrease your volume. You have been warned)

http://picosong.com/c5eF/

Overall, this is one worthwhile game to add to your library. There is nothing like showing off an mp3 to people you know and say you made this yourself with Cosmic DJ.

You sequence your instruments one by one, then the games mixes it for you in to an exportable track when you're finished playing around. I bought Cosmic DJ in the Humble Bundle Summer Sale. I think I paid around £0.69 for it and for that price it both entertained and annoyed me for a while.

The game has 5 pros I can think of.

Cut Scenes
I think the cut scenes are the best thing about the game and they had me laughing quite a few times. Steve3 is what made the cut scenes entertaining.

Music
The backing tracks in the levels are actually really good as standalone tracks.

Sliders
I really like the fact there were volume sliders, that I did not expect and they were great for muting unwanted instruments.

Exporting
Anything you create can be exported as an mp3 which is great.

Price
It was very cheap when I bought it and I think it was a fair price, I don't think I would pay full price for it though.

This game is very simple and very fun to just mess around with.\nBeing able to create simple beats and feel like you have control over how the song plays out is a cool idea and is brought out well considering. It is easy to go in and create a beat of your own with and you do not need to be a wiz with music making to do it well.  However this is where the negatives start to kick in.  In the game you go between 4-5 different instruments and create beats with essentially 4 different notes....and that's it really. There are bonus loops or instruments that can appear and give you the option of changing your current instrument with the new one or have the option of selecting new music in general.  Besides this there is no other way to make or alter music.  This is where the simplicity will be seen as a negative.  You are not able to fade music in or out, change the BPM, and there is no way to edit your samples the way YOU want after you create them.  The game will automatically edit the samples together which may make your song sound better or worse.  It is a shame that if you want to make advanced samples or create your own songs your out of luck really.  It took me 3 hours to go through the entire story" section but I will say I had a lot of fun playing through it.  Even though you have limits to the kind of music you can make it is still a fun expereince that is worth that little bit of money it costs to play it.  People looking for an advanced music maker to make samples and great tracks would probably get nothing from this
date:
but for players looking for a simple and fun music creation game to mess around and have fun with then there is nothing wrong with this game.  Did I forget to mention any song you finish you can save and export it to your music library on you computer to listen to whenever you want (even if the songs are just 1 minute long).  A lot of neat ideas in this game I just wish there would be options for more advanced options to give people freedom to create even more awesome tracks.    However because the game only costs a couple of dollars my negatives really are just minor.        Cosmic DJ get's a 7/10 From me. Short, sweet, and to the point.
This psychedelic trip of a game is very fun to mess around with. Overall there are about 6 'Areas' to play through and each one has 4 miniature 'stages' where you can play around with 5 different instruments/voxes. The backing tracks can only be changed a tiny bit through progression, the more stuff you put into a song the more options you might get to add into it even further.
The story's funny to me personally, I rather liked the 'far out' voice of the narrator and the weird things that happen along the way. There's a charm to how simple this game is and honestly I couldn't stop playing once I picked it up.
The soundtrack is awesome, especially since the player has quite a bit of influence over it, and there's even more charm to be found in a game that lets you export your little creations to a folder on your computer for later listenings (it's automatic, so don't expect a deep, in-depth music creator here).

Even though the game is incredibly short (expect 2-4 hours depending on how much you want to screw around with the tracks) I found that it was definitely worth the price of admission. It doesn't hurt that I also got this game on sale for less than a dollar, but honestly even if it weren't on sale I'd still recommend it.
